Situation1: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story: The lunch rush at the supermarket always tests my patience, but today, the line snakes all the way to the frozen foods. I force a smile, scanning groceries and making small talk, trying to keep things moving. My manager expects me to be friendly, efficient, and calm, even as the register beeps and customers sigh impatiently. But my phone vibrates in my pocket—a reminder that the midday prayer is about to begin. The regular backup imam is out of town, and everyone at the mosque is counting on me to lead. I picture the congregation gathering, waiting for me to step forward, their trust in my guidance heavy on my shoulders. My heart pounds as I glance at the clock, torn between the duty to my customers and the responsibility to my community. Each beep of the scanner feels louder, each minute more urgent. I can’t be in two places at once, but both roles demand all of me right now.
